TopicTitle: Any good youtube channel/ guide compilation of tutorials for KSP?

Articles.Content:
Title says everything.

Do you have an specific youtube channel that is dedicated to KSP or atleast has alot of video tutorials?

Hello, and welcome to KSP! I have started a youtube channel with a couple of videos to get you started, I will be adding videos weekly as well. And I have a twitch stream where I teach KSP all day, every Tuesday, hope that helps!

https://www.youtube.com/channel/UChMERvh-alDd3kzy0ZyFMlA

https://www.twitch.tv/rocketpcgaming
The best quide to tutorials remains The Drawing Board, which is stickied here.
Also, if you're interested in RSS, I'm running a playthrough series on my channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCSiTjUVe4FLhmkGNBq-NWjw

Here's a very comprehensive series of tutorials for beginners to Kerbal Space Program.  I watched him and learned a lot.  They should hopefully get you started on your KSP journey.

 

https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCwnE0czz6mprmGRfrtaYcjg

I would personally recommend Scott Manley. He has a ton of very comprehensive, in depth analysis, well reputed tutorials. 

Edited June 10, 2016 by Mycroft

While I'd certainly recommend Scott Manley, beware that his rendezvous/docking explanation is generally not recommended.  Personally, I like his method for getting an encounter (it is highly fuel efficient, although some players might just force an encounter in a single orbit), but don't think new players should bother with his glacial suggestion for docking: once you learn to land you should understand chasing the target marker and putting it on the prograde/retrograde makers and keeping them aligned.  It makes things much easier that way (but at least start with Scott's slow encounter method.  You don't want to do a proper "align the target" docking with a high speed encounter).

On June 10, 2016 at 9:03 AM, wumpus said:

While I'd certainly recommend Scott Manley, beware that his rendezvous/docking explanation is generally not recommended.  Personally, I like his method for getting an encounter (it is highly fuel efficient, although some players might just force an encounter in a single orbit), but don't think new players should bother with his glacial suggestion for docking: once you learn to land you should understand chasing the target marker and putting it on the prograde/retrograde makers and keeping them aligned.  It makes things much easier that way (but at least start with Scott's slow encounter method.  You don't want to do a proper "align the target" docking with a high speed encounter).

Actually, I find it quite useful. He was the one who taught me how to dock.
